title: The New Kid in Robotics Club

chapters.text: Jake stood frozen in the doorway of the robotics club, clutching his backpack straps so tightly his knuckles turned white. Twenty pairs of eyes stared back at him. The room buzzed with the sounds of small motors and excited chatter that instantly died when he appeared. A tall girl with bright blue hair stepped forward. "You lost?" she asked, raising an eyebrow. Jake swallowed hard. After three schools in two years, he knew the drill – lay low, don't stand out, find one decent person to sit with at lunch. But something about this school made him want to try differently. "Actually, I signed up yesterday," he said, his voice cracking slightly. The girl's serious expression suddenly broke into a wide grin. "Perfect timing! We need someone for the controller team. I'm Mia." She extended her hand, not noticing the whispers from a group of boys in the corner.

Jake hesitantly shook her hand, his palm sweaty against her firm grip. "I'm Emma, club president," she said with a warm smile. "Don't mind those guys." The whispers from the corner grew louder, and Jake noticed a tall boy with spiky hair nudging his friends. Emma led Jake to a table covered with robot parts, circuit boards, and tools. "We're building battle bots this semester," she explained, picking up a small metal frame. Jake's eyes widened with interest as she demonstrated how the pieces fit together. The tension in his shoulders eased slightly. A carton of chocolate milk sat on the edge of the table, and when Emma accidentally bumped it while reaching for a screwdriver, Jake's quick reflexes saved it from spilling all over their project. "Nice catch," Emma laughed. "Maybe you should be our goalkeeper instead of our newest robotics member."

Jake's face turned bright red as laughter rippled through the room. "I, uh, actually do play soccer," he mumbled, finally stepping fully into the robotics lab. The tall boy who had made the joke - his name tag read "Carlos, Club President" - walked over and clapped Jake on the shoulder. "Just teasing, new kid. Anyone who can catch a flying circuit board that fast has good reflexes." Carlos guided Jake to an empty workstation where parts were scattered across the table. "We're building battle bots this semester. Think you can handle it?" Jake nodded, setting down his backpack and picking up a small motor. His fingers stopped trembling as he examined the parts, a small smile forming. The other students returned to their projects, the awkward moment passing. Jake hadn't expected his first day to start with catching flying electronics, but maybe this robotics club would be okay after all.

The tall girl who had thrown the circuit board walked over and introduced herself as Mia, the team captain. "Nice reflexes," she said with a grin, pointing to a workstation with tools scattered across it. "We're building battle bots for the competition next month." Jake nodded and followed her, noticing a shelf filled with trophies and a large safety poster showing proper equipment use, including protective eyewear and a bright red HELMET with "SAFETY FIRST" printed on it. The room buzzed with activity as students tinkered with metal parts, soldered wires, and tested small motors. A robot with spinning wheels zoomed past Jake's feet, making him jump back. Mia laughed and handed him a screwdriver. "Don't worry. The dangerous stuff comes later. Want to help me fix this servo motor?"

Jake nodded nervously, stepping forward into the robotics club room. "Sure, I can try," he said, his voice barely above a whisper. The girl who had spoken held up a small motor with wires sticking out in different directions. She had curly hair and a friendly smile that made Jake's shoulders relax a little. As he sat down beside her at the workbench, she showed him where the servo was broken. Jake carefully took the tiny screwdriver she offered and began to work on the motor. His fingers moved with surprising confidence as the other club members gradually returned to their own projects. The room filled with the sounds of clicking keyboards and whirring test robots. For the first time since moving to this new school, Jake felt like he might belong somewhere. The servo motor was tricky, but fixing things was something he understood perfectly.

Jake carefully adjusted the tiny screwdriver, his tongue poking out in concentration as he worked on the servo motor. The other students gradually gathered around him, their earlier stares turning to curious glances. "How did you learn to do that?" asked a girl with curly hair and glasses. Jake shrugged without looking up, his fingers moving with surprising confidence for someone who had been so nervous moments ago. "My dad repairs appliances," he explained, connecting two wires that made the small motor hum to life. The robotics teacher, Mr. Wilson, nodded approvingly from across the room. "Looks like we have someone with natural talent here," he announced, causing Jake to blush slightly. But for the first time since entering the room, Jake felt his tight grip on his backpack straps loosen as something even better took its place – a small, genuine smile.

Jake felt a warmth spread through his chest as several club members waved him over to an empty seat. The robotics teacher, Mr. Chen, handed him a small kit with gears and wires. "Welcome to the team," he said. Over the next hour, Jake worked alongside Emma, who patiently showed him how to connect the circuits. When their robot successfully completed its first task, the whole club cheered. Jake's robot wasn't the fanciest or fastest, but it worked, and that was enough. As the bell rang signaling the end of the meeting, Jake packed up his things, no longer a stranger but a member of something special. Walking out with his new friends, Jake realized sometimes the scariest doorways led to the best places. He couldn't wait to come back tomorrow.
